name: 2-naphthalenecarboxylic acid, 3-hydroxy-
Reason: The target compound is 3-hydroxy-2-naphthalenecarboxylic acid. The basic unit, naphthalene, has a melting point of 80.2°C. The presence of two functional groups, the carboxylic acid group and the hydroxy group, will influence the melting point. Carboxylic acid, due to hydrogen bonding and increased molecular weight, can raise the melting point by approximately 40–50°C. The hydroxy group, which also forms hydrogen bonds but has a smaller molecular weight than the carboxylic acid, might raise the melting point by about 10–20°C. Both groups are ortho to each other, which could enhance the hydrogen bond interactions due to proximity, raising the melting point even further, possibly by an additional 5–10°C.
Prediction: The predicted melting point considering the effects of the functional groups would be approximately 80.2 (base naphthalene) + 40 (carboxylic acid) + 15 (hydroxy group) + 7.5 (enhanced hydrogen bonding due to ortho position) = 142.7°C

name: 2-naphthalenecarboxylic acid, 3-hydroxy-
Reason: The target compound is 3-hydroxy-2-naphthalenecarboxylic acid. The basal structure is naphthalene, which has a melting point of 80.2°C. The introduction of a carboxylic acid group typically raises the melting point significantly due to its ability to form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds, increased polarity, and due to the addition of more heavy atoms, contributing to an increase of perhaps 40-50°C. The hydroxy group also contributes to hydrogen bonding and adds polarity to the molecule; it might be expected to raise the melting point by approximately 10-20°C. Both the hydroxy and carboxyl groups are ortho to each other on the naphthalene ring, which can facilitate even stronger intermolecular hydrogen bonding due to their proximity, potentially adding another 5-10°C. Taking into account the sum of these effects, the rise in melting point could be estimated as 40°C for the carboxyl group, 15°C for the hydroxy group, and 5°C for the enhanced hydrogen bonding effects.
Prediction: The predicted melting point is 80.2 (base naphthalene) + 40 (carboxylic acid group) + 15 (hydroxy group) + 5 (enhanced hydrogen bonding due to ortho position) = 140.2°C
